questions.text: Below the pectineal line the lymphatic spread is to nodes (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) the lymphatic drainage above and below the pectinate line is different. Above the pectinate line lymphatic drainage is to the inferior mesenteric lymph nodes and below the pectinate line the lymphatic drainage is to the superficial inguinal lymph node.

questions.text: Internal sphincter of rectum is formed by: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) internal anal sphincter is formed by the condensation of the circular muscle fibres. Option B that is puborectalis is a sling like muscle which lies at the anorectal junction and form anorectal ring. Option C that is longitudinal muscle fibres condense to form the external anal sphincter.

choices.text: Drained by superficial inguinal lymph node

questions.text: True statement about upper half of anal canal is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) upper half of the anal canal is insensitive to pain. Option B is wrong as upper part of the anal canal is drained by inferior mesenteric lymph nodes and not the superficial inguinal lymph nodes. Option C is wrong as upper part of the anal canal is lined by the columnar epithelium. Option D that is wrong as upper half of the anal canal is supplied by superior rectal artery and not the superior mesenteric artery.

choices.text: Completely lined by stratified squamous epithelium
Drained by veins forming portosystemic anastomosis
Part below pectinate line is supplied by inferior rectal artery

questions.text: Not true about the anal canal is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anal canal is not completely lined by stratified squamous epithelium, below the pectinate line it is lined by squamous epithelium and above the pectinate line it is lined by columnar epithelium. Option B is correct as Anal canal is supplied by pudendal nerve. Option C is correct as at the pectinate line we have portosystemic anastomosis as the part above the pectinate line is drained by superior rectal vein which ultimately ends up in the portal circulation and the part below the pectinate line is drained by inferior rectal vein which ultimately drains into internal iliac vein which is a part of the systemic circulation. Option D is correct as the part of anal canal below the pectinate line is supplied by inferior rectal artery.

questions.text: A patient With external hemorrhoids develops pain while passing stools. The nerve mediating this pain is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) the area of the anal canal below the pectinate line is pain sensitive and the pain fibres from this area are carried by the inferior rectal nerve via pudendal nerve. Option A that is the hypogastric nerve supplies the upper part of the anal canal and is pain insensitive. Hypogastric nerve plexus also supply the internal anal sphincter.

questions.text: In an adult male, on per rectal examination, the following structures can be felt anteriorly except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is the answer as on per rectal examination internal iliac lymph nodes are felt posteriorly and not anteriorly. Bulb of penis, Prostate and enlarged seminal vesicle is felt anteriorly.

questions.text: The following are important in maintenance of normal fecal continence except: (AIIMS Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) haustral valves are not responsible for the anal continence. Anorectal angulation, Rectal innervation and internal sphincter have a definitive role to play in rectal continence.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of anorectal ring? (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) anorectal ring is formed by external anal sphincter, puborectalis and internal anal sphincter. Anococcygeal raphe do not have any role in the formation of anorectal ring.

questions.text: External anal sphincter is innervated by: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) External anal sphincter is innervated by inferior rectal nerve which has a root value of S234.

questions.text: Dentate line measurement from anal margin: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Anal canal is 4 cm in size and the distance of the dentate line from anal verge is 2 cm and distance of anorectal ring from the dentate line is 2 cm.

questions.text: Most common site of chronic fissure in ano: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fissure in ano is a longitudinal slit in the anoderm from anal verge till dentate line. Most common site of occurence of fistula in ano is posterior in midline at 6’o clock position.

questions.text: Percentage of GTN used in fissure: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) We can use nitroglycerine ointment and diltiazem ointment for the treatment of anal fissure. We use 0.2 % nitroglycerine for the treatment of anal fissure and 2 % diltiazem gel that is CCB for the treatment of anal fissure.

questions.text: All are treatment of acute fissure in ano except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) we do not do external sphicterotomy for the treatment of anal fissure.(instead we do lateral sphincterotomy of internal anal sphincter). Treatment options for anal fissure include: Option A, we can advise conservative treatment for patients of anal fissure which includes hot sitz bath and stool softener. Option B is another treatment option for treatment of anal fissure which includes dilation under general anaesthesia. It is called Lord’s dilatation. Option C Is Lateral sphicterotomy and it is also a treatment option for anal fissure.

choices.text: Sits in a basin containing warm antiseptic lotion
Sits in a basin containing molten wax

questions.text: Sitz Bath consists of which of the following ? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hot sitz bath is a popular treatment option which is advised for patients of anal fissure and haemorrhoids and it is basically an advise given to patient in which he is supposed to sit in the warm antiseptic solution with is anal area immersed in it. This helps in relaxing the sphincter and helps to provide symptomatic relief to the patients.

questions.text: Rectal examination should not be done in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anal fissure is a very painful condition so per rectal examination in these patients in opd basis is avoided as it causes extreme discomfort to the patient. Option B is fistula in ano, per rectal examination is not contraindicated in fistula in ano infact it can help to locate internal opening in some cases . Option C is prolapsed piles with bleeding, in these patients we definitely do a per rectal examination to reposit the piles back into rectum and to rule out any underlying mass or lesion. Option D is anal stenosis and it is not a contraindication for per rectal examination.

questions.text: Internal sphincterotomy is the treatment of choice for:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Internal sphincterotomy in the treatment option for fissure in ano. Option A that is plies is treated by hot sitz bath or by banding or sclerotherapy. Option D that is carcinoma is treated by chemotherapy or surgery depending on the stage and extent of the disease .

questions.text: Anal fissure best diagnosed by: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Anal fissure is best diagnosed by history and clinical examination. In these patients we have a typical history of constipation, streaking of blood over stool and pain during defecation and during examination we fill find sentinel piles and hypertrophied papillae and this is enough to make a diagnosis of anal fissure. Anoscopy is not needed to diagnose anal fissure but it can help in patients of fistula in ano. PR examination is actually contraindicated in patients of anal fissure. USG has no role in the diagnosis of anal fissure.

questions.text: A sentinel pile indicates: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) sentinel piles indicate a chronic fissure. Chronic fissure is characterized by Canoe shaped ulcer + Sentinel pile + Hypertrophied papillae.

questions.text: Most common site for anal fissure is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) the most common site for anal fissure is posteriorly in the midline which in lithotomy position indicates 6 o’clock position.

questions.text: Commonest type of anorectal abscess is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Most common type of anorectal abscess is perianal abscess. Ischiorectal, submucosal and pelvi rectal are other types but the most common type of anorectal abscess is perianal.

questions.text: Most common cause of anorectal abscess is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Theory behind formation of anorectal abscess is known as “cryptoglandular theory of anorectal abscess” and it involves inflammation of anal glands which spread laterally to involve perianal area leading to abscess.

questions.text: Most common anorectal fistula: (AIIMS Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) According to the Park’s classification of anorectal fistulae they are divided into 4 types. 4 types are Intersphincteric, transsphincteric, suprasphincteric and extrasphincteric. Out of these the most common type of anorectal fistula is Inter Sphincteric. Others in decreasing order of occurance are : Trans sphicteric> Supra Sphincteric> Extra Sphincteric.

questions.text: An AIDS patient presents with fistula in ano. His CD. count is below 50. Treatment of choice is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) in AIDS there is defective healing of the tissue and defective repair so the interventions like fistulectomy is not effective. Rather we can go with a draining seton which will help get rid of the infection and promote the healing of the tissue by the natural process.

questions.text: The treatment of choice in fistula in ano: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Fistulotomy is the treatment of choice for low fistula in ano, which is the most common type. The procedure involves laying open the entire fistulous tract to allow it to heal from the base by secondary intention. This technique is simple, has a high success rate, low recurrence, and preserves anal continence in most cases, provided the tract does not involve significant portions of the sphincter complex. It is especially favored for superficial or low intersphincteric and transsphincteric fistulas, where the risk of damaging the sphincter is minimal. Postoperative care includes keeping the wound clean and allowing it to granulate over time. Fistulotomy is widely practiced and has been supported by multiple surgical guidelines and studies as the standard management for low anal fistulas. Incorrect Answers: A. Anal dilatation Incorrect – Anal dilatation is not used in the management of fistula in ano. It was once a treatment for chronic anal fissure or tight anal sphincters but is now largely obsolete due to risks such as anal incontinence. It has no role in addressing a fistulous tract. B. Fissurotomy Incorrect – Fissurotomy refers to the surgical treatment of anal fissures, not fistulas. It involves incision or excision of the fissure area to relieve tension and promote healing. Since fissures and fistulas are entirely different pathologies, this procedure is irrelevant in the context of fistula in ano. C. Fistulectomy Incorrect but close – Fistulectomy involves complete excision of the fistulous tract rather than laying it open. While it can also be used for fistula treatment, it is associated with more tissue loss, longer healing times, and a potentially greater risk of sphincter damage compared to fistulotomy. Therefore, although effective in selected cases, it is not the first-line treatment and hence not the treatment of choice.

questions.text: High or low fistula in ano is termed according to its internal opening present with reference to: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Anorectal ring is formed by puborectalis muscle, internal and external anal sphincter. Any fistula which opens above this is called as a high lying fistula and any fistula which opens below this is known as a low lying fistula.

questions.text: Ideal investigation for fistula-in-ano is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) First investigation which we do for patients of fistula in ano is fistulogram. Best investigation available for patients of fistula in ano is MRI.

questions.text: All are true regarding solitary rectal ulcer syndrome except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A is correct because SRUS is located on anterior or anterolateral rectal wall, 7–10 cm from anal verge. Option B is correct as patients of solitary rectal ulcer syndrome can present with a full thickness rectal prolapse or internal prolapse. Option C is wrong as these ulcers are neither malignant nor predispose to malignancy. Option D is correct as some factor responsible for straining while defecation or constipation is present in most of the patients with solitary rectal ulcer syndrome and most of the patients respond to non-operative therapy (high fber diet, defecation training to avoid straining, laxatives or enema).

questions.text: Most common site of SRUS: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B is correct because SRUS is located on anterior or anterolateral rectal wall, 7–10 cm from anal verge. Although this is the most common site solitary rectal ulcer can be present anywhere from the sigmoid to the anorectal junction.

questions.text: Treatment of solitary rectal ulcer are all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C & D) Treatment option for solitary rectal ulcer syndrome consists of non operative therapy, surgery and rectopexy. • Non-operative therapy (high fber diet, defecation training to avoid straining, laxatives or enema) is effective in majority of the patients. • Surgery (either abdominal or perineal repair of prolapse) is reserved for highly symptomatic patients, who have failed all medical intervention. • Rectopexy corrects anterior rectal wall prolapse. Banding and sclerosent injection are not given.

questions.text: Jeep's disease is also known as: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pilonidal sinus is a disease which leads to a midline sinus formation in the lower back and coccyx region due to prolonged trauma or exposure to hairs and it ultimately leads to a cavity which communicates with the exterior and the track is lined by a granulation tissue. As this is more common in males who have lot of hairs and who have jobs which involves increased friction in this area like military personel or jeep drivers. It Is also called as a Jeep’s Disease.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding pilonidal sinus except: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pilonidal sinus is a disease which leads to a midline sinus formation in the lower back and coccyx region due to prolonged trauma or exposure to hairs and it ultimately leads to a cavity which communicates with the exterior and the track is lined by a granulation tissue. As this is more common in males who have lot of hairs in inguinal and gluteal region. Option B is correct as this disease is more common in sacrococcygeal region. Option C is correct as it is a difficult condition to treat and even after the treatment until the underlying predisposing factor persists it has tendency to recur. Option D is correct as obesity is one of the risk factors for pilonidal sinus.

questions.text: Hemorrhoids managed by manual reduction: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hemorrhoids are classified into 4 types . Type 1: Bleeding Type 2: Bleeding plus prolapse during defecation . Type 3: Bleeding plus prolapse with manual reposition. Type 4: Bleeding plus permanent prolapse.

choices.text: Can be palpated on DRE in absence of complications
Band ligation is most commonly done office procedure
Stapled hemorrhoidectomy causes less postoperative pain

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about hemorrhoids?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B is wrong as we con not palpate haemorrhoids on DRE if there is no associated complication along with this . Option A is correct as pruritis is not a common feature of haemorrhoids. Option C is true as band ligation is a very common office procedure performed for internal second and third degree piles. Option D is correct as stapled hemorrhoidectomy is a better procedure and it causes less postoperative pain as compared to other open procedures. So stapled hemorrhoidectomy is preferred.

choices.text: Skin tag is not seen in these cases

questions.text: External hemorrhoids below the dentate line are: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) external haemorrhoids are present below the dentate line and are painful. Option B is wrong, as external haemorrhoids are painful we do not use ligation and banding as a treatment option, these are reserved for internal haemorrhoids. Option C is wrong as skin tags is a feature of external haemorrhoids. Option D is wrong as haemorrhoids do not have any malignant potential.

questions.text: Commonest complication following hemorrhoidectomy (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Among the options given commonest complication of hemorrhoidectomy is urinary retention. But if you consider overall the most common complication of hemorrhoidectomy is pain and second most common is urinary retention. Hemorrhage, infection and fecal impaction are other complications but are not the most common once.

questions.text: Best investigation to diagnose piles is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Proctoscopy is best investigation available to make the diagnosis of piles. Option A is false as even though proctosigmoidoscopy can help to diagnose haemorrhoids there is no need to subject the patient to a more extensive investigation. Option B and C are not useful to make a diagnosis of haemorrhoids.

questions.text: Five-day self subsiding pain is diagnostic of: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Five day self subsiding pain is characteristic feature of thrombosed external piles. It is called so as it resolves on its own in five days. Anal fissure presents as pain but it is not associated with five day self subsiding pain. Fistula in ano does not present as a painful condition of the perianal region. Internal hemorroids are painless.

choices.text: They are common causes of painless bleeding
They cannot be per rectally palpated

questions.text: The following are true of hemorrhoids except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) haemorrhoids are not arterial dilations. Hemorrhoids are basically normal anatomical cushions which are composed of venules, arterioles, muscle fibers and elastic tissue. When these normal anatomical cushions become lax they present as haemorrhoids.

choices.text: External hemorrhoids are proximal to dentate line
Internal hemorrhoids bleed profusely and painless
Internal hemorrhoids are covered by anoderm.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about hemorrhoids? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) internal haemorrhoids are present proximal to dentate line they present with a painless bleeding. Option A is wrong as portal hypertension is not the most common cause. Most common cause is infact chronic constipation. Option B is wrong as external haemorrhoids are present distal to dentate lines not proximal to dentate line. Option C is false as external haemorrhoids are covered with anoderm.

questions.text: The length of a standard proctoscope is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is correct as length of standard proctoscope is 10 cm which is 4 inches. Also remember length of rigid sigmoidoscope is 25 cm that is 10 inches Length of flexible sigmoidoscope is 60 cm that is 24 inches. Length of colonoscope is 160 cm that is 64 inches.

questions.text: Muscle which is primarily responsible for rectal continence: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Muscle which is primarily responsible for rectal continence is puborectalis. Puborectalis forms a sling around the rectosigmoid junction and is the main muscle responsible for rectal continence. Option A and B that is external and internal anal sphincter are also helpful in maintaining the continence but the main muscle responcible for this is puborectalis.

questions.text: What procedure has been shown in the following figure ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option B. Milligan morgan : It is an open haemorrhoidectomy Option C. Ferguson hemorrhoidectomy : It is a closed haemorrhoidectomy

questions.text: Which layer of muscle joins together to form the internal anal sphincter?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The inner circular muscle joins to form the internal anal sphincter. the subcutaneous, superficial, and deep external sphincter surrounds it. The deep external anal sphincter is an extension of the puborectalis muscle.

choices.text: Incision and drainage in the intergluteal cleft
Incision and drainage lateral to the intergluteal cleft
En bloc excision of the sinus tract with flap reconstruction

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with redness, pain, and fluctuance in the intergluteal cleft, about 4 cm posterior to the anus. There is considerable hair adjacent to the lesion. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pilonidal disease can either present acutely with an abscess or chronically (prior drainage). Acute disease is best treated with incision and drainage of the abscess lateral to theintergluteal cleft, as opposed to directly in the cleft because the latter creates constant friction in the wound and therefore heals poorly. Although there is not a “gold standard treatment” for chronic pilonidal cyst management, the preferred treatment option depends on if the pilonidal cyst is simple or complex. Excision with primary closure off the midline for a simple, noninfected pilonidal cyst is the most appropriate treatment option

choices.text: Broad-spectrum antibiotics and rectal examination with the patient under anesthesia

questions.text: Twelve hours after hemorrhoidal banding, a 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department reporting rectal and abdominal pain and an inability to urinate. His temperature is 102°F and heartrate is 110 beats per minute. Management consists of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sepsis after the treatment of hemorrhoids has been described after banding, sclerotherapy, and stapled hemorrhoidectomy. The patient usually presents within the first 12 hours after the procedure but can present in a delayed fashion. The most common symptoms are severe perineal pain, fevers, and urinary retention. IV antibiotics with coverage of gram-negative rods and anaerobes. Examination with the patient under anesthesia is recommended to rule out a necrotizing infection that may require debridement.

questions.text: The chemotherapeutic agents commonly used and favored for anal canal carcinoma are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The Nigro protocol consists of 5-FU and mitomycin C combined with radiation therapy. This cures nearly 80% of cases. Recurrent cases require an abdominoperineal resection. Carmustine is a nitrosurea that is used in brain cancer.

questions.text: A patient presents pain during defecation with on and off bleeding. Which of the following medical therapies results in the greatest healing rates for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Given their distal location of anal fissure, they cause exquisite pain with each defecation, often accompanied by blood on the toilet paper. To effect healing, softening of the stool is essential,using fiber and stool softeners, as is relaxation of the sphincter. Numerous topical agents have been used with varying degrees of success, including 2% lidocaine jelly, nitroglycerin ointment(0.2%), topical diltiazem, topical arginine (a nitric oxide donor), and topical bethanechol (a muscarinic agonist). However, the best rate of healing with nonoperative treatment is via injection of botulinum toxin, which causes temporary paralysis of the sphincter muscle. Recent studies suggest that healing rates with botulinum toxin approach those of surgery, althoughsurgery remains the gold standard for refractory cases.

choices.text: Fixation of the rectum with prosthetic sling (Ripstein repair)

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presents with rectal prolapse. She has a history of chronic constipation.Colonoscopy findings are negative. Treatment would be best achieved via:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Procidentia (rectal prolapse) is much more common in women than men. It is more common in elderly women. It involves all layers of the rectum and starts 6 to 7 cm from the anal verge. As a general rule, adults with rectal prolapse require surgery, whereas children can often be managed nonoperatively. As such,abdominal procedures are used for younger, lower-risk patients and perineal procedures for older,higher-risk patients. The perineal rectosigmoidectomy has a 15%recurrence rate and is a good option for older patients. The Thiersch anal encirclement is no longer used. Another well-accepted perineal operation isthe Delorme procedure, which involves reefing the rectal mucosa

choices.text: Drainage of an anorectal abscess rarely results in a persistent fistula-in-ano.
The internal opening is generally easily identifiable.
Fistulas are categorized based on their relationship to the anal mucosa.
Surgical treatment is determined by the internal and external opening of the fistula.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding fistula-in-ano?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The external opening of the fistula is usually obvious, whereas the internal one is often hard to identify. Surgical treatment is determined by the location of the internal and external openings and the course of the fistula tract and may include simple fistulotomy, draining or cutting seton, fibrin glue injection, fibrin plug, ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT)procedure, or anorectal advancement flap. Gently injecting hydrogen peroxide or methylene blue into the external opening may help identify the internal opening.

questions.text: The most common cause of a rectovaginal fistula is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A rectovaginal fistula is most often due to an obstetric injury after a vaginal delivery in association with episiotomy typically in primigravida. Other causes include inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn disease more than ulcerative colitis).

questions.text: A screening colonoscopy identifies a broad sessile villous appearing lesion of the rectum beginning 4 cm above the anal verge and extending 5 cm proximally. Biopsies show a villous adenoma with dysplasia. Endorectal ultrasound (EUS) shows that the muscularis propria is not involved. No suspicious lymph nodes are seen. Which of the following approaches is the most appropriate for the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A villous adenoma with the dimensions given has a 30%–50% chance of harboring cancer. An endoscopic biopsy represents a very limited sample size and is not an adequate proof of the lesion’s precise histologic characteristics. In this instance, the finding of dysplasia suggests a high probability of cancer elsewhere in the adenoma. A complete, full-thickness transanal excision of the lesion should be performed so that if a carcinoma is present, its depth of penetration can be assessed accurately.

questions.text: Which of the following chemotherapy regimens is used for treating patients with rectal carcinoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) FOLFOX regimen 5-Fluorouracil-based regimens with leucovorin and oxaliplatin (FOLFOX) reduce recurrence and improve survival in patients with colorectal carcinoma.

choices.text: Tumor within 8 cm of the anal verge
T2 tumor without lymph node involvement

questions.text: Transanal local excision can be done in rectal carcinoma patients with all of the following tumour features except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) T2 tumor without lymph node involvement T2 rectal cancers are managed by transabdominal resection.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient has a carcinoma extending to the extra rectal tissues, but no lymph node involvement was seen. What would be the stage of this carcinoma according to Duke's classification?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Stage B On MRI, a rectal carcinoma extending to the extra rectal tissue but has no lymph node involvement belongs to stage B. According to Duke's classification, Stage B tumor is of moderate intensity. It is associated with around 70% 5-year survival rate.

choices.text: Staging of local and distant metastases
Assessment of nodal involvement and mesorectal fascia status

questions.text: What is the role of MRI in rectal cancer management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Assessment of nodal involvement and mesorectal fascia status MRI pelvis is the preferred modality for staging rectal cancer, particularly for assessing the depth of tumor invasion, nodal involvement, and the status of the mesorectal fascia, which is crucial for surgical planning.

choices.text: Improve survival and quality of lif

questions.text: A patient with Stage IV rectal cancer and liver metastases is planned for palliative care. What is the role of chemotherapy in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Improve survival and quality of life In Stage IV rectal cancer with distant metastases, chemotherapy (e.g., FOLFOX or FOLFIRI regimens) is used palliatively to prolong survival, reduce tumor burden, and improve quality of life. It is not curative in advanced disease.

choices.text: Hartmann’s operation is done in old debilitated patients
Per rectal examination can diagnose only 10% of cases
Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur
Growth confined to rectal wall is stage A of Modified Duke staging

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is false regarding carcinoma rectum?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Per rectal examination can diagnose only 10% of cases

questions.text: A 40-years old male presented with reducible rectal prolapse with history of constipation from the last 10 years, redundant sigmoid with fecal matter, best form of management for this patient:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Anterior resection

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented to your OPD with this problem. What is the preferred treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Delorme procedure

questions.text: The image depicted below shows the outcome following a surgical intervention performed on a patient presenting with rectal prolapse. Kindly identify the specific procedure employed.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Thiersch wiring Thiersch wiring is a surgical technique for managing certain types of rectal prolapse. It involves applying wires or sutures to the rectal mucosa to create a supportive framework and provide mechanical support to the rectum.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in a newborn with rectal biopsy showing aganglionosis, hypertrophied nerve trunks, and staining for acetylcholine esterase?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hirschsprung’s disease Hirschsprung’s disease presents in infants with abdominal distension, constipation, and green vomiting due to functional obstruction from muscular spasms in the distal colon and internal anal sphincter. Diagnosis is confirmed through contrast enema, revealing a distally contracted and proximally dilated colon with a transition zone, and rectal biopsy, which shows absent ganglion cells in the submucosal and myenteric plexus alongside hypertrophied nerve fibers in the aganglionic area. At least two biopsies, each 3mm in diameter and including both mucosa and submucosa, are necessary for diagnosis.

questions.text: A neonate was brought to the pediatrician on day 7 of life with bilious vomiting and failure to pass meconium. On examination, the abdomen was distended. and X-Ray showed distended bowel loops. Due to suggestive family history, the resident suspected Hirschsprung's disease. What is the gold standard investigation for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rectal biopsy A rectal biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease.

questions.text: A 4-day old neonate who has not yet passed meconium developed abdominal distension. A barium enema was done and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hirschsprung's disease The given clinics along with the barium study is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. The image depicts barium enema showing dilated right colon with a transition zone in the mid descending colon.
